title: Iterators
subject: Java
theory:
Iterator is an interface used to loop through Collections.
Safe way to modify collection during iteration.

*   `hasNext()`: boolean
*   `next()`: returns element
*   `remove()`: removes current element

examples.explanation: Only available for Lists, not Sets.

common_mistakes.correction: It advances the cursor twice, skipping elements or crashing. Assign `next()` to a var.

interview_questions.question: Why use Iterator instead of for-loop?
interview_questions.answer: Iterator allows safe removal of elements (`it.remove()`) which for-each loop does not support.

real_world_use_cases.description: Implementing `Iterable` allows your custom usages to work with for-each loops.

exam_notes: Enumeration is the legacy version of Iterator.
Fail-fast iterators throw exception if list modified externally.
summary: Iterators provide a standard way to access elements.
